ReportSection.name: Agreement
ReportSection.title: Confidentiality Agreement

ReportItem.yes: Yes, I agree to abide by the confidentiality agreement
ReportItem.no: No, I do not agree to abide by the confidentiality agreement

ReportSection.ReportItem:
CONFIDENTIALITY AGREEMENT

This Confidentiality Agreement is given to the Canadian Frailty Network (CFN) in consideration of my role as a Grant Reviewer to review grant application(s) (Information) for CFN.

I acknowledge that as part of my role as a Grant Reviewer for CFN I may be given access to information that is of a personal, confidential and/ or proprietary nature, for example: names, e-mail addresses, financial information, funding applications and their status, trade secrets, research data, and any other information for the purpose of fulfilling my obligations.

I, therefore agree:

  • To hold all Information in trust and strict confidence and agree that it shall be used only for the purposes required to fulfill my role as a Grant Reviewer, and shall not be used for any other purpose, or disclosed to any third party.
  • To keep all Information in my control or possession in a secure location to which only I and other persons who are authorized to view this information, and have signed a confidentiality agreement with CFN, have access.
  • To take all necessary steps to keep all Information secure and to protect such Information from unauthorized use, reproduction or disclosure.
  • To maintain the absolute confidentiality of all Information in recognition of the privacy and proprietary rights of others at all times.
  • To comply with all privacy laws and regulations, which apply to the collection, use and disclosure of personal information.
  • At the conclusion of my role as a Grant Reviewer, or upon demand by CFN, to return all Information, including prototypes, code, written notes, photographs, sketches, models, memoranda or notes taken, to CFNâ€™s possession and the responsible manager/director.
  • Not to disclose any Information to any employee, consultant or third party unless they agree to execute and be bound by the terms of this agreement and have been approved by CFN in an official, legal capacity.

I understand that a breach of confidentiality or misuse of Information could result legal action.

I understand that this Agreement survives the termination of my relationship with CFN.

The laws of Ontario, Canada shall govern this Agreement and its validity, construction and effect.

I fully understand and accept responsibilities set above relating to personal, confidential and/or proprietary Information:

  • Personal Information is any information about an "identifiable individual".
  • Confidential Information is any information which is designated by CFN as confidential.
  • Proprietary Information is any information which is designated by CFN as proprietary like trade secrets, and research data.
{$item}

ReportSection.name: External Review
ReportSection.Instructions:
1. Please score all sections. You can use decimals in your scores.
  2. Competition Goal: To advance previously funded CFN research evidence into practice thereby, ultimately strengthening Canada's healthcare system and improving care of Canadians living with frailty.
  3. Because of the limited overall budget and expected high interest for this competition, the budget/budget justification will be a major evaluation criterion. Note: Increasing budgetary requests will be expected to produce a proportionately greater impact and will undergo commensurate scrutiny as to their ability to achieve these impacts.
  4. Proposals that secure cash and/or in kind matching contributions beyond the minimum 1:1 match will be at an advantage.

ReportItemSet.title: {getText(RP_KT_APPLICATION,INFORMATION,FILE_NUMBER,0,{$user_id},0)} - {$user_name}
ReportItemSet.ReportItem:
Project Leader:{getText(RP_KT_APPLICATION,INFORMATION,CFN_PL,0,{$user_id},0)}
Project ID:{getText(RP_KT_APPLICATION,INFORMATION,FILE_NUMBER,0,{$user_id},0)}
Project Title:{getText(RP_KT_APPLICATION,INFORMATION,TITLE,0,{$user_id},0)}
{$item}

Please enter a score from 0 to 4 in each input box below for each criteria. Scores can include up to two decimal places.

1. Lay Summary

Is the lay summary described in a way that can be easily understood by those without prior experience of the subject. Please note that the lay summary It is not a slight modification of the scientific abstract or a simplification of the study; a well-written lay summary allows the public to understand research and its value, impact, and applications. Lay summaries also help juries evaluate research grant applications and facilitate use of the research by government, the public and private sectors, and the community at large.

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The lay summary is highly technical and uses scientific terms and abbreviations that are not suitable for a general audience. The lay summary is overly technical and uses some scientific terms and abbreviations that are mostly unnecessary. The lay summary is well written and mostly utilizes non-technical/scientific terms that help a general audience better understand the project goals and objectives. The lay summary is extremely well written. The use of technical/scientific terms and abbreviations are all but eliminated except when absolutely necessary. The summary is clear and concise and allows the general audience to understand the project goals and objectives and ultimately appreciate the value of the KT study. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

2. Quality of Idea

How well does the applicant describe the study so that it addresses what has been asked. The applicant was asked to: a. describe any success stories or real-world impacts that resulted from prior KT activities related to the prior CFN-funded research project and also discuss the relevancy of this KT proposal to the prior research project, b. describe the overall goal and objectives of the study and provide distinct outputs that support advances in health-related knowledge, health research, health care, health systems, and/or health outcomes for the care of Canadians living with frailty and c. describe the hypothesis and rationale of the study and articulate why the proposal is considered to have the potential to change the care of older Canadians living with frailty.

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
Relevancy of KT study to prior CFN-funded research project is not provided; overall goal and objectives do not relate to Canadians living with frailty and/or are not consistent with the hypothesis and rationale. KT study is somewhat relevant to the prior CFN-funded research project but does not build upon the prior KT activity associated with the research project; overall goal and objectives are described with outputs provided; hypothesis and rationale is reasonable. KT study is directly relevant to the prior CFN-funded research project but only partially builds upon the prior KT activity associated with the research project; overall goal and objectives are described with measurable outputs provided; hypothesis and rationale are well thought through. KT study is directly relevant to the prior CFN-funded research project and completely builds upon the prior KT activity associated with the research project; overall goal and objectives clearly demonstrate the potential for continued high impact on the care of Canadians living with frailty; hypothesis and rationale is well thought through and clearly articulated. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

3. Quality of the Idea - Evaluation Plan of Study Impact

How well does the applicant describe how the impact of the study will be measured and evaluated? The applicant was asked to clearly describe how you plan on measuring and evaluating the impact of your proposal on the care of older adults living with frailty.

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The applicant fails to provide a description of the way the study impact will be measured and evaluated. The applicant provides a very poor description of the methods and metrics that will be used to measure and evaluate the impact of the study and most of the metrics utlized are not appropriate to properly measure and evaluate impact. The applicant provides a good description of the methods and metrics that will be used to measure and evaluate the impact of the study and most of the metrics utlized are appropriate to properly measure and evaluate impact. The applicant provides an excellent description of the methods and metrics that will be used to measure and evaluate the impact of the study and all of the metrics utlized are appropriate to properly measure and evaluate impact. In addition, the applicant provides details on how they intend on measuring the sustainability of the impact beyond the study period. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

4. Importance of Idea

How well does the applicant describe how the study will contribute to advancing health-related knowledge, health research, health care, health systems and/or health outcomes related to the care of Canadians living with frailty.

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
It is not clear how the study relates to Canadians living with frailty and/or it is not clear how the study will contribute to any of the areas described above. The study is somewhat relevant to Canadians living with frailty and is somewhat applicable to at least one of the areas described above. The study is relevant to Canadians living with frailty and clearly contributes to at least one of the areas described above. The study is highly relevant to Canadians living with frailty and it is clear how it will contribute to at least one of the areas described above. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

5. Approach

How well does the applicant describe the study so that it addresses what has been asked in this section. The applicant was asked to: a. describe the approaches and methods used in the study and why they are appropriate to meet the goals and objectives and deliver upon the proposed output(s) and provide any additional budget justification (in addition to what is in budget document) as it relates to the approaches and methods. (The proposal should be developed using an appropriate KT strategy based on a KT framework identified in the April 2012 Knowledge Translation Framework for Ageing and Health from the World Health Organization (http://www.who.int/ageing/publications/knowledge_translation.pdf)), b. provide timelines showing when goals, objectives and outputs will be reached and provide any additional budget justification (in addition to what is in budget document) as it relates to the goals, objectives and outputs, and c. describe the potential barriers and challenges related to achieving the proposed goals and objectives and how applicant intends on overcoming these barriers and challenges. Applicants were also asked to describe their mitigation strategy?

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
There is significant concern about meeting the goals and objectives of the study based on the approach described. The timeline provided is not sufficiently detailed and does not include a mitigation strategy. There is no budget justification in this section or the budget document. The approach for meeting the study goals and objectives is reasonable but needs improvement. A timeline is provided but lacks specific details, some challenges/barriers are described and a rudimentary mitigation strategy is provided. A budget justification is provided, although additional details would have been helpful. The approach for meeting the study goals and objectives is reasonable, and uses an appropriate KT strategy. A detailed timeline is provided with consideration given to potential barriers along the way and a reasonable mitigation strategy is included. A satisfactory budget justification is provided. A comprehensive approach for meeting the study goals and objectives is well described and uses an appropriate KT strategy. The timelines provided are specific and reasonable, with potential barriers and challenges well considered and addressed in the mitigation strategy. A very detailed budget justification is provided. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

6. Experience, Expertise and Resources

How well does the applicant describe the study so that it addresses what has been asked in this section. The applicant was asked to: a. describe the expertise and experience of each Principal Investigator, Co-investigator, Partner and other critical team member to show that he/she can lead and deliver on the proposed outputs and achieve the goals and objectives of this proposal, b. provide an estimate on the number of hours per week (contribution) for each Principal Investigator, Co-investigator, Partner and other critical team member that will be working on the study and describe why this is an appropriate level of engagement and/or commitment to deliver the proposed outputs and achieve the goals and objectives of this proposal, and c. for each Principal Investigator, Co-investigator, Partner and other critical team member describe why the environment (academic institution and/or other organization) is appropriate to enable the conduct and success of the project?

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The project team has limited experience/expertise with frailty and has not allocated sufficient time for the completion of the project. There is significant concern regarding the environment of critical team members and lack of appropriate partners and collaborators. The project team has a few members with experience/expertise in frailty and may have underestimated the amount of time required to complete the project. The environment of critical team members is appropriate for completion of the project. All project team members have some direct experience/expertise in frailty. Team members have dedicated appropriate time for the completion of the project. The critical team members are from an environment that will enable the success of the proposed project. All project team members have in-depth experience/expertise in frailty. Team members have dedicated appropriate time for the completion of the project, with some "buffer" time in case of delays. All team members are from environments that will enable the success of the proposed project. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

7. Capacity Building

Is the number of HQP and their level of training/experience and role/activities appropriate and meaningful for the study. Please note that CFN funded proposals must contribute to the development of HQP through their inclusion as fully involved team members. Note: Meaningful involvement in the research components of a CFN-funded project would include such activities such as data collection, data synthesis, report writing, etc., but would exclude tasks that are more related to administration and/or coordination (e.g. data entry, meeting scheduling, minute taking, completion and distribution of paperwork, etc.).

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The proposal does not have a plan for the development of HQP. The project roles and responsibilities of each HQP have been somewhat described/delineated, but do not appear to be meaningful. The project roles and responsibilities of each HQP have been satisfactorily described/delineated, and appear to be meaningful. The project roles and responsibilities of each HQP have been very well described/dilineated and each HQP will be meanignfully involved in the study and in fact their role/responsibilities go beyond the traditional HQP. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

8. Project Networking and Engagement

How well does the applicant describe the study so that it addresses what has been asked in this section. The applicant was asked to: a. describe the networking and engagement planned for this project across disciplines and sectors (note: CFN asks that projects represent a collaborative effort of different Investigators in more than one discipline and at more than one Institution), b. describe how knowledge users (e.g. patients/families, decision makers, stakeholders, practitioners) will be involved in the study in a meaningful manner (note: meaningfully involved participation of knowledge users includes assisting in the planning and execution of the study).

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The project involves investigators from only one discipline and institution. The study has a poorly designed plan to involve knowledge users. The project involves investigators from a couple of different disciplines and institutions, and has a plan to involve different types of knowledge users; however, in a less than meaningful way. The project involves investigators from a few unique disciplines and institutions. The study has a reasonable plan to involve different types of knowledge users in a meaningful way. Project involves investigators from a diverse range of disciplines and many different institutions. The study has a comprehensive plan to involve different types of knowledge users in a meaningful way. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

9. Partnerships

Do the applicants have the appropriate partners to carry out the study and do the partners appear fully committed to, and meaningfully involved in the project? Note: KT proposals must include partners who have committed cash or eligible in-kind contributions on a 1:1 basis to that of CFN funding. As an example, if the PI requests $100,000 from CFN then the PI must secure an additional minimum $100,000 in partner contributions.)

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
Applicants have not established partnerships for the proposed study or have listed partners that have not committed to the minimum 1:1 partner contribution (1:1; partner funding:CFN funding). Applicants have partners that have committed to the minimum 1:1 partner contribution, and all partner contributions are in-kind (i.e., no cash). In addition, many of the partners appear to be appropriate (i.e., lack the expertise, experience etc...) for the planned study and thus are likely to be meaningfully involved in the study. Applicants have partners that have committed to the minimum 1:1 partner contribution, and a small percentage (<10%) of the partner contribution is cash, with the remainder being in-kind. In addition, most partners appear to be appropriate (i.e., have the expertise, experience etc...) for the planned study and are meaningfully involved in the study. Applicants have partners that have committed more than the minimum 1:1 partner contribution, and a significant percentage (>10%) of the partner contribution is cash, with the remainder being in-kind. In addition, all partners appear to be appropriate (i.e., have the expertise, experience etc...) for the planned study and are meaningfully involved in the study. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

{round( {multiply( {divide( {add({getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_EX_REVIEW,KT_EX_1,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_EX_REVIEW,KT_EX_2,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_EX_REVIEW,KT_EX_3,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_EX_REVIEW,KT_EX_4,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_EX_REVIEW,KT_EX_5,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_EX_REVIEW,KT_EX_6,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_EX_REVIEW,KT_EX_7,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_EX_REVIEW,KT_EX_8,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_EX_REVIEW,KT_EX_9,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)} )} , 36)} , 5)} ,2 )} (Score converted out of 5)
General Comments - Please provide any general comments that are not captured in above section: {$item}

ReportSection.ReportItem: You need to accept the confidentiality agreement before you have access to any of the review materials.

ReportItem.message: Thank you for submitting your External Review.

8. Project Networking and Engagement

How well does the applicant describe the study so that it addresses what has been asked in this section. The applicant was asked to: a. describe the networking and engagement planned for this project across disciplines and sectors (note: CFN asks that projects represent a collaborative effort of different Investigators in more than one discipline and at more than one Institution), b. describe how knowledge users (e.g. patients/families, decision makers, stakeholders, practitioners) will be involved in the study in a meaningful manner (note: meaningfully involved participation of knowledge users includes assisting in the planning and execution of the study).

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The project involves investigators from only one discipline and institution. The study has a poorly designed plan to involve knowledge users. The project involves investigators from a couple of different disciplines and institutions, and has a plan to involve different types of knowledge users; however, in a less than meaningful way. The project involves investigators from a few unique disciplines and institutions. The study has a reasonable plan to involve different types of knowledge users in a meaningful way. Project involves investigators from a diverse range of disciplines and many different institutions. The study has a comprehensive plan to involve different types of knowledge users in a meaningful way. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

9. Partnerships

Do the applicants have the appropriate partners to carry out the study and do the partners appear fully committed to, and meaningfully involved in the project? Note: KT proposals must include partners who have committed cash or eligible in-kind contributions on a 1:1 basis to that of CFN funding. As an example, if the PI requests $100,000 from CFN then the PI must secure an additional minimum $100,000 in partner contributions.)

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
Applicants have not established partnerships for the proposed study or have listed partners that have not committed to the minimum 1:1 partner contribution (1:1; partner funding:CFN funding). Applicants have partners that have committed to the minimum 1:1 partner contribution, and all partner contributions are in-kind (i.e., no cash). In addition, many of the partners appear to be appropriate (i.e., lack the expertise, experience etc...) for the planned study and thus are likely to be meaningfully involved in the study. Applicants have partners that have committed to the minimum 1:1 partner contribution, and a small percentage (<10%) of the partner contribution is cash, with the remainder being in-kind. In addition, most partners appear to be appropriate (i.e., have the expertise, experience etc...) for the planned study and are meaningfully involved in the study. Applicants have partners that have committed more than the minimum 1:1 partner contribution, and a significant percentage (>10%) of the partner contribution is cash, with the remainder being in-kind. In addition, all partners appear to be appropriate (i.e., have the expertise, experience etc...) for the planned study and are meaningfully involved in the study. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

10. Budget Justification

Does the applicant justify the need for the budget items listed and are the costs associated with each item reasonable? Please review the Budget document (Excel document) and if necessary refer to Section 3.2.1 (Approach) for additional budget justification. Note applicants were advised that, because of the limited overall budget amount (for this KT competition) and the expected high interest in this competition, the budget justification within submitted proposals will be a major evaluation criterion.

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The budget was not appropriately justified and is unreasonable. Parts of the budget are appropriately justified. The entire budget is justified, although some components appear unreasonable. The entire budget is justified and very reasonable. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

11. Budget Amount and Potential Impact

Does the potential impact of the study justify the requested total study budget? Note that there was no maximum budget amount stipulated to applicants and thus applicants were advised that increasing budgetary requests will be expected to produce a proportionately greater impact and will undergo commensurate scrutiny as to their ability to achieve these impacts.

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The impact of the study is expected to be at the micro-level and thus the budget amount cannot be justified. In this context "micro-level" impact refers to the study affecting a very small number of individuals, not necessarily representative of most older adults living with frailty and thus the study impact will not reach much beyond the small number of citizens in the study. The impact of the study is expected to be at the meso-level and thus the budget amount may be appropriate. In this context "meso-level" impact refers to the study affecting a small number of individuals in a single province. However, the magnitude of the impact on this small group is likely to be high, although the ability to scale and spread these results in the future are likely low. The impact of the study is expected to be at the macro-level and thus the budget amount is appropriate. In this context "macro-level" impact refers to either of the following scenarios:
  1. study affects a large population of individuals, representative of most older adults living with frailty and thus the future impact should be applicable nation-wide, although the magnitude of the impact on this large population may be minor, or
  2. study affects a small number of indivuduals, but the impact is likely to be significant and the ability to scale and spread the results in the future are likely very high.
 The impact of the study is expected to be at the macro-level and thus the budget amount is appropriate. In this context "macro-level" impact refers to the study affecting a large population of individuals, representative of all older adults living with frailty and thus the impact should be nation-wide. In addition, the magnitude of the impact to this large population is likely to be very significant. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

{add({getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_1,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_2,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_3,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_4,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_5,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_6,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_7,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_8,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_9,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_10,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_11,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)} )} (Score out of 44)

{round( {multiply( {divide( {add({getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_1,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_2,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_3,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_4,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_5,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_6,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_7,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_8,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_9,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_10,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)}, {getNumber(RP_KT_REVIEW,KT_KTC_REVIEW,KT_KTC_11,{$user_id},{$my_id},0)} )} , 44)} , 5)} ,2 )} (Score converted out of 5)
General Comments - Please provide any general comments that are not captured in above section: {$item}

ReportSection.name: Fit Review
ReportSection.Instructions:
1. Please score all sections. You can use decimals in your scores.
  2. Competition Goal: To advance previously funded CFN research evidence into practice thereby, ultimately strengthening Canada's healthcare system and improving care of Canadians living with frailty.
  3. Because of the limited overall budget and expected high interest for this competition, the budget/budget justification will be a major evaluation criterion. Note: Increasing budgetary requests will be expected to produce a proportionately greater impact and will undergo commensurate scrutiny as to their ability to achieve these impacts.
  4. Proposals that secure cash and/or in kind matching contributions beyond the minimum 1:1 match will be at an advantage.

ReportItemSet.title: {getText(RP_KT_APPLICATION,INFORMATION,FILE_NUMBER,0,{$user_id},0)} - {$user_name}
ReportItemSet.ReportItem:
Project Leader:{getText(RP_KT_APPLICATION,INFORMATION,CFN_PL,0,{$user_id},0)}
Project ID:{getText(RP_KT_APPLICATION,INFORMATION,FILE_NUMBER,0,{$user_id},0)}
Project Title:{getText(RP_KT_APPLICATION,INFORMATION,TITLE,0,{$user_id},0)}
{$item}

Please enter a score from 0 to 4 in each input box below for each criteria. Scores can include up to two decimal places.

1. Lay Summary

Is the lay summary described in a way that can be easily understood by those without prior experience of the subject. Please note that the lay summary It is not a slight modification of the scientific abstract or a simplification of the study; a well-written lay summary allows the public to understand research and its value, impact, and applications. Lay summaries also help juries evaluate research grant applications and facilitate use of the research by government, the public and private sectors, and the community at large.

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The lay summary is highly technical and uses scientific terms and abbreviations that are not suitable for a general audience. The lay summary is overly technical and uses some scientific terms and abbreviations that are mostly unnecessary. The lay summary is well written and mostly utilizes non-technical/scientific terms that help a general audience better understand the project goals and objectives. The lay summary is extremely well written. The use of technical/scientific terms and abbreviations are all but eliminated except when absolutely necessary. The summary is clear and concise and allows the general audience to understand the project goals and objectives and ultimately appreciate the value of the KT study. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

2. Quality of Idea

How well does the applicant describe the study so that it addresses what has been asked. The applicant was asked to: a. describe any success stories or real-world impacts that resulted from prior KT activities related to the prior CFN-funded research project and also discuss the relevancy of this KT proposal to the prior research project, b. describe the overall goal and objectives of the study and provide distinct outputs that support advances in health-related knowledge, health research, health care, health systems, and/or health outcomes for the care of Canadians living with frailty and c. describe the hypothesis and rationale of the study and articulate why the proposal is considered to have the potential to change the care of older Canadians living with frailty.

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
Relevancy of KT study to prior CFN-funded research project is not provided; overall goal and objectives do not relate to Canadians living with frailty and/or are not consistent with the hypothesis and rationale. KT study is somewhat relevant to the prior CFN-funded research project but does not build upon the prior KT activity associated with the research project; overall goal and objectives are described with outputs provided; hypothesis and rationale is reasonable. KT study is directly relevant to the prior CFN-funded research project but only partially builds upon the prior KT activity associated with the research project; overall goal and objectives are described with measurable outputs provided; hypothesis and rationale are well thought through. KT study is directly relevant to the prior CFN-funded research project and completely builds upon the prior KT activity associated with the research project; overall goal and objectives clearly demonstrate the potential for continued high impact on the care of Canadians living with frailty; hypothesis and rationale is well thought through and clearly articulated. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

3. Quality of the Idea - Evaluation Plan of Study Impact

How well does the applicant describe how the impact of the study will be measured and evaluated? The applicant was asked to clearly describe how you plan on measuring and evaluating the impact of your proposal on the care of older adults living with frailty.

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The applicant fails to provide a description of the way the study impact will be measured and evaluated. The applicant provides a very poor description of the methods and metrics that will be used to measure and evaluate the impact of the study and most of the metrics utlized are not appropriate to properly measure and evaluate impact. The applicant provides a good description of the methods and metrics that will be used to measure and evaluate the impact of the study and most of the metrics utlized are appropriate to properly measure and evaluate impact. The applicant provides an excellent description of the methods and metrics that will be used to measure and evaluate the impact of the study and all of the metrics utlized are appropriate to properly measure and evaluate impact. In addition, the applicant provides details on how they intend on measuring the sustainability of the impact beyond the study period. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

4. Importance of Idea

How well does the applicant describe how the study will contribute to advancing health-related knowledge, health research, health care, health systems and/or health outcomes related to the care of Canadians living with frailty.

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
It is not clear how the study relates to Canadians living with frailty and/or it is not clear how the study will contribute to any of the areas described above. The study is somewhat relevant to Canadians living with frailty and is somewhat applicable to at least one of the areas described above. The study is relevant to Canadians living with frailty and clearly contributes to at least one of the areas described above. The study is highly relevant to Canadians living with frailty and it is clear how it will contribute to at least one of the areas described above. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

5. Approach

How well does the applicant describe the study so that it addresses what has been asked in this section. The applicant was asked to: a. describe the approaches and methods used in the study and why they are appropriate to meet the goals and objectives and deliver upon the proposed output(s) and provide any additional budget justification (in addition to what is in budget document) as it relates to the approaches and methods. (The proposal should be developed using an appropriate KT strategy based on a KT framework identified in the April 2012 Knowledge Translation Framework for Ageing and Health from the World Health Organization (http://www.who.int/ageing/publications/knowledge_translation.pdf)), b. provide timelines showing when goals, objectives and outputs will be reached and provide any additional budget justification (in addition to what is in budget document) as it relates to the goals, objectives and outputs, and c. describe the potential barriers and challenges related to achieving the proposed goals and objectives and how applicant intends on overcoming these barriers and challenges. Applicants were also asked to describe their mitigation strategy?

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
There is significant concern about meeting the goals and objectives of the study based on the approach described. The timeline provided is not sufficiently detailed and does not include a mitigation strategy. There is no budget justification in this section or the budget document. The approach for meeting the study goals and objectives is reasonable but needs improvement. A timeline is provided but lacks specific details, some challenges/barriers are described and a rudimentary mitigation strategy is provided. A budget justification is provided, although additional details would have been helpful. The approach for meeting the study goals and objectives is reasonable, and uses an appropriate KT strategy. A detailed timeline is provided with consideration given to potential barriers along the way and a reasonable mitigation strategy is included. A satisfactory budget justification is provided. A comprehensive approach for meeting the study goals and objectives is well described and uses an appropriate KT strategy. The timelines provided are specific and reasonable, with potential barriers and challenges well considered and addressed in the mitigation strategy. A very detailed budget justification is provided. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

6. Experience, Expertise and Resources

How well does the applicant describe the study so that it addresses what has been asked in this section. The applicant was asked to: a. describe the expertise and experience of each Principal Investigator, Co-investigator, Partner and other critical team member to show that he/she can lead and deliver on the proposed outputs and achieve the goals and objectives of this proposal, b. provide an estimate on the number of hours per week (contribution) for each Principal Investigator, Co-investigator, Partner and other critical team member that will be working on the study and describe why this is an appropriate level of engagement and/or commitment to deliver the proposed outputs and achieve the goals and objectives of this proposal, and c. for each Principal Investigator, Co-investigator, Partner and other critical team member describe why the environment (academic institution and/or other organization) is appropriate to enable the conduct and success of the project?

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The project team has limited experience/expertise with frailty and has not allocated sufficient time for the completion of the project. There is significant concern regarding the environment of critical team members and lack of appropriate partners and collaborators. The project team has a few members with experience/expertise in frailty and may have underestimated the amount of time required to complete the project. The environment of critical team members is appropriate for completion of the project. All project team members have some direct experience/expertise in frailty. Team members have dedicated appropriate time for the completion of the project. The critical team members are from an environment that will enable the success of the proposed project. All project team members have in-depth experience/expertise in frailty. Team members have dedicated appropriate time for the completion of the project, with some "buffer" time in case of delays. All team members are from environments that will enable the success of the proposed project. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

7. Capacity Building

Is the number of HQP and their level of training/experience and role/activities appropriate and meaningful for the study. Please note that CFN funded proposals must contribute to the development of HQP through their inclusion as fully involved team members. Note: Meaningful involvement in the research components of a CFN-funded project would include such activities such as data collection, data synthesis, report writing, etc., but would exclude tasks that are more related to administration and/or coordination (e.g. data entry, meeting scheduling, minute taking, completion and distribution of paperwork, etc.).

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The proposal does not have a plan for the development of HQP. The project roles and responsibilities of each HQP have been somewhat described/delineated, but do not appear to be meaningful. The project roles and responsibilities of each HQP have been satisfactorily described/delineated, and appear to be meaningful. The project roles and responsibilities of each HQP have been very well described/dilineated and each HQP will be meanignfully involved in the study and in fact their role/responsibilities go beyond the traditional HQP. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

8. Project Networking and Engagement

How well does the applicant describe the study so that it addresses what has been asked in this section. The applicant was asked to: a. describe the networking and engagement planned for this project across disciplines and sectors (note: CFN asks that projects represent a collaborative effort of different Investigators in more than one discipline and at more than one Institution), b. describe how knowledge users (e.g. patients/families, decision makers, stakeholders, practitioners) will be involved in the study in a meaningful manner (note: meaningfully involved participation of knowledge users includes assisting in the planning and execution of the study).

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The project involves investigators from only one discipline and institution. The study has a poorly designed plan to involve knowledge users. The project involves investigators from a couple of different disciplines and institutions, and has a plan to involve different types of knowledge users; however, in a less than meaningful way. The project involves investigators from a few unique disciplines and institutions. The study has a reasonable plan to involve different types of knowledge users in a meaningful way. Project involves investigators from a diverse range of disciplines and many different institutions. The study has a comprehensive plan to involve different types of knowledge users in a meaningful way. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

9. Partnerships

Do the applicants have the appropriate partners to carry out the study and do the partners appear fully committed to, and meaningfully involved in the project? Note: KT proposals must include partners who have committed cash or eligible in-kind contributions on a 1:1 basis to that of CFN funding. As an example, if the PI requests $100,000 from CFN then the PI must secure an additional minimum $100,000 in partner contributions.)

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
Applicants have not established partnerships for the proposed study or have listed partners that have not committed to the minimum 1:1 partner contribution (1:1; partner funding:CFN funding). Applicants have partners that have committed to the minimum 1:1 partner contribution, and all partner contributions are in-kind (i.e., no cash). In addition, many of the partners appear to be appropriate (i.e., lack the expertise, experience etc...) for the planned study and thus are likely to be meaningfully involved in the study. Applicants have partners that have committed to the minimum 1:1 partner contribution, and a small percentage (<10%) of the partner contribution is cash, with the remainder being in-kind. In addition, most partners appear to be appropriate (i.e., have the expertise, experience etc...) for the planned study and are meaningfully involved in the study. Applicants have partners that have committed more than the minimum 1:1 partner contribution, and a significant percentage (>10%) of the partner contribution is cash, with the remainder being in-kind. In addition, all partners appear to be appropriate (i.e., have the expertise, experience etc...) for the planned study and are meaningfully involved in the study. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

10. Budget Justification

Does the applicant justify the need for the budget items listed and are the costs associated with each item reasonable? Please review the Budget document (Excel document) and if necessary refer to Section 3.2.1 (Approach) for additional budget justification. Note applicants were advised that, because of the limited overall budget amount (for this KT competition) and the expected high interest in this competition, the budget justification within submitted proposals will be a major evaluation criterion.

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The budget was not appropriately justified and is unreasonable. Parts of the budget are appropriately justified. The entire budget is justified, although some components appear unreasonable. The entire budget is justified and very reasonable. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}

11. Budget Amount and Potential Impact

Does the potential impact of the study justify the requested total study budget? Note that there was no maximum budget amount stipulated to applicants and thus applicants were advised that increasing budgetary requests will be expected to produce a proportionately greater impact and will undergo commensurate scrutiny as to their ability to achieve these impacts.

Unacceptable
(score = 0) 		Borderline
(score = 1) 		Good/Solid
(score = 3) 		Excellent
(score = 4) 		Your score
(Max 4)
The impact of the study is expected to be at the micro-level and thus the budget amount cannot be justified. In this context "micro-level" impact refers to the study affecting a very small number of individuals, not necessarily representative of most older adults living with frailty and thus the study impact will not reach much beyond the small number of citizens in the study. The impact of the study is expected to be at the meso-level and thus the budget amount may be appropriate. In this context "meso-level" impact refers to the study affecting a small number of individuals in a single province. However, the magnitude of the impact on this small group is likely to be high, although the ability to scale and spread these results in the future are likely low. The impact of the study is expected to be at the macro-level and thus the budget amount is appropriate. In this context "macro-level" impact refers to either of the following scenarios:
  1. study affects a large population of individuals, representative of most older adults living with frailty and thus the future impact should be applicable nation-wide, although the magnitude of the impact on this large population may be minor, or
  2. study affects a small number of indivuduals, but the impact is likely to be significant and the ability to scale and spread the results in the future are likely very high.
 The impact of the study is expected to be at the macro-level and thus the budget amount is appropriate. In this context "macro-level" impact refers to the study affecting a large population of individuals, representative of all older adults living with frailty and thus the impact should be nation-wide. In addition, the magnitude of the impact to this large population is likely to be very significant. {$item}
Comments: Please provide comments to justify your score: {$item}
